docs.title: Site
docs.text: If you are not redirected, go to English.

docs.title: Structural Explainability
docs.text:
Structural Explainability develops foundational structural constraints on representational substrates intended to support accountability and interoperability under persistent interpretive disagreement.

This site presents the theoretical results, formal constructions, and adoption guidance that together define a neutral substrate for accountability-oriented systems.

The work establishes what must be true of any such substrate prior to concrete ontology design, policy frameworks, or domain-specific implementation.

docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Structural Explainability works on the design of neutral representational substrates that preserve stable reference and accountability under persistent disagreement.

The results are theoretical and constraint-based. They do not prescribe domain ontologies, policies, or implementations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Modern accountability systems must function across legal, political, ethical, and analytical disagreement.

Structural Explainability studies the structural commitments that such systems cannot avoid if disagreement is persistent, and if reference and accountability are to remain stable over time.

The focus is on:

  • Ontological neutrality
  • Identity and persistence
  • Extension stability under incompatible interpretations

Interpretation, explanation, and evaluation are externalized by design.

docs.title: Is this a protocol?
docs.text: No. It is a set of structural constraints.

docs.title: Is this an ontology?
docs.text: No. It constrains what ontologies may assume at their foundation.

docs.title: Does this resolve disagreement?
docs.text: No. It preserves disagreement while maintaining accountability.

docs.title: For Implementers
docs.text:
Structural Explainability does not require adoption of any specific ecosystem or tooling.

Implementers may use these results to:

  • Evaluate existing systems
  • Design neutral cores
  • Separate substrate from interpretation

docs.title: Standards Mapping
docs.text:
Structural Explainability is compatible with, but not reducible to, existing standards.

Mappings may be constructed to legal, policy, or domain standards without embedding them into the substrate itself.

This enables compliance without ontological capture.

docs.title: Accountable Entities (AE)
docs.text:
Accountable Entities instantiate the identity-regime results by mapping named entity kinds to the six necessary and sufficient identity regimes.

This construction is structural, not domain-specific.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Make identity regimes operational
  • Enable consistent reference across records and systems
  • Support accountability without semantic overcommitment

docs.title: Contextual Evidence and Explanations (CEE)
docs.text:
CEE defines the structural forms required to represent explanations, evidence groupings, and contextual justification under disagreement.

CEE does not assert causal models, normative conclusions, or interpretive outcomes.

docs.title: Role
docs.text:
• Externalize explanation from the substrate
  • Preserve contestability
  • Support multiple explanatory frameworks over the same records

docs.title: Exchange Protocol (EP)
docs.text:
The Exchange Protocol defines neutral record structures for representing accountable exchanges.

It specifies entities, relationships, exchanges, and envelopes in a time-parametric, interpretation-agnostic form.

docs.title: Design Principle
docs.text: The protocol represents what happened structurally, without asserting why it happened or whether it was justified.

docs.title: Interpretation Boundary
docs.text: The interpretation boundary defines where external legal, ethical, or policy frameworks may act upon substrate records.

docs.title: Principle
docs.text:
Interpretation may constrain or evaluate records, but must not alter the neutral structural core.

This boundary preserves interoperability across incompatible interpretive regimes.

docs.title: Annotation Standard
docs.text:
This project uses a structured annotation vocabulary to document decisions, constraints, and alternatives directly alongside code and configuration.

The annotation standard improves explainability without enforcing semantics or policy.

docs.title: Licensing and Citation
docs.text:
Licensing is determined per repository.

  • Code: open-source licenses (e.g., MIT, Apache 2.0)
  • Papers: Creative Commons Attribution licenses

Citation guidance is provided in each artifact repository.

docs.title: Neutral Substrate
docs.text:
This result establishes an impossibility theorem:

Any representational substrate that remains stable under incompatible extensions must be pre-causal and pre-normative.

The result constrains what may appear at the foundational layer of any ontology intended to function as a shared substrate across persistent disagreement.

docs.title: Artifacts
docs.text:
• Formal proof (Lean 4)
  • Narrative exposition (Paper 100)

docs.title: Implication
docs.text:
Embedding causal models, values, obligations, or policy judgments at the substrate level entails a loss of neutrality or extension stability.

Such commitments therefore cannot be present at the foundational layer of a substrate intended to remain stable under persistent disagreement.

docs.title: Identity Regimes
docs.text:
This result shows that exactly six identity-and-persistence regimes are necessary and sufficient for accountability-oriented substrates under neutrality assumptions.

Each regime corresponds to a distinct mode of persistence, identity conditions, and reference stability.

docs.title: Artifacts
docs.text:
• Formal proof (Lean 4)
  • Narrative exposition (Paper 200)

docs.title: Implication
docs.text:
Any accountability-oriented system that seeks substrate stability under persistent disagreement must implicitly or explicitly commit to these regimes.

Under the neutrality and independence constraints, the set of regimes is neither reducible nor extensible without loss of expressive adequacy.
